title: Harry Potter Meets â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™ in Racy SNL Sketch With Ron Romance, Naked Quidditch and Jason Momoa
description:
The Wizarding World is taking on â€œHeated Rivalry.â€

	On this weekâ€™s â€œSNL,â€ host Finn Wolfhard starred as Harry Potter in a sketch mocking the new HB
body:
The Wizarding World is taking on â€œHeated Rivalry.â€

	On this weekâ€™s â€œSNL,â€ host Finn Wolfhard starred as Harry Potter in a sketch mocking the new HBO series adaptation of the fantasy novels. But in this version, thanks to being â€œhastily rewritten after the success of a certain other HBO show,â€ Harry quickly becomes enamored with Ron (Ben Marshall) and the show is renamed â€œHeated Wizardry.â€ Itâ€™s also said to be â€œthe first series written entirely by girls who wear tails.â€
	

	Of course, wand and broom puns and innuendo arrive quickly, as â€œthe only thing hotter than hockey is Quidditch.â€ After seeing Harry and Ronâ€™s meet cute, Harry is seen flying away from Ron on the Quidditch pitch without any bottoms and more sexy Hogwarts shenanigans take place.


	In the segment, James Austin Johnson plays Severus Snape, Jason Momoa stops by to play Hagrid, Ashley Padilla plays Professor McGonagall and Kenan Thompson takes on Alastor Moody.

schema.headline: Harry Potter Meets â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™ in Racy SNL Sketch With Ron Romance, Naked Quidditch and Jason Momoa

title: Filmmaker Cedric Klapisch Collects French Cinema Award at Familial, Culture Ministry Ceremony
description: Flanked by his closest collaborators, director CÃ©dric Klapisch collected this yearâ€™s French Cinema Award at a warm, familial ceremony at Franceâ€™s Mi
body:
Flanked by his closest collaborators, director CÃ©dric Klapisch collected this yearâ€™s French Cinema Award at a warm, familial ceremony at Franceâ€™s Ministry of Culture on Jan. 15.

	Joined by his longtime screenwriter Santiago Amigorena and his emblematic actor Zinedine Soualem â€” key creative partners for more than three decades â€” along with the cast of his latest feature, â€œColors of Time,â€ Klapisch was celebrated for a career that has consistently looked beyond national borders.
	

	Launched by Unifrance in 2016, the French Cinema Award honors a figure whose work has helped carry Gallic cinema worldwide. Past recipients include Isabelle Huppert, Juliette Binoche, Virginie Efira, and filmmakers Olivier Assayas, Rebecca Zlotowski, and Olivier Nakache and Ã‰ric Toledano. Klapisch, however, doesnâ€™t just promote his films abroad: his work is defined by movement and global exchange, crystallized in the critically and commercially adored â€œSpanish Apartmentâ€ series, which across three features and an Amazon series follows an extended clan across three continents.


	Accepting the prize, Klapisch pointed to travel as a central artistic catalyst, noting that a promotional tour for 2002â€™s â€œPot Luckâ€ â€” the first in the series â€” directly inspired its follow-up, â€œRussian Dolls.â€

	â€œSome journeys give birth to new films,â€ he said. â€œTravel is a fundamental part of my cinema. Thatâ€™s the reason I made â€˜Pot Luckâ€™ â€” and why Iâ€™m standing here today.â€

	Raised in Paris, Klapisch launched his career with an MFA at NYUâ€™s Tisch School of the Arts, an experience he said left a lasting mark.
	

	â€œI began my adult life in the U.S., and today I honestly wonder whether young French people still feel the same pull to go there,â€ he added. â€œItâ€™s less obvious now. Meanwhile, something new is happening: major American actors and directors are coming to France. That simply didnâ€™t exist before. Thereâ€™s been a reversal. Movement no longer flows in the same direction.â€ 

	Reflecting on what he called â€œa strange, pivotal momentâ€ for the film business, Klapisch turned his focus closer to home. â€œThereâ€™s constant talk about box office numbers, admissions, and international circulation â€” and this is even more pronounced abroad,â€ he said. â€œBut France is truly unique because of its system, and the CNC in particular. I will always defend the CNC. It must continue to exist. It supports cinematic creation. Iâ€™ve often said the CNC is a protected space where creation can happen, and I believe deeply in that model.â€

	Fittingly, CNC president GaÃ«tan Bruel was on hand to hear the praise, joining French Culture Minister Rachida Dati, Unifrance president Gilles PÃ©lisson, and executive director Daniela Elstner in saluting Klapisch at this yearâ€™s Unifrance Rendez-Vous in Paris.



	

					Daniela Elstner, Cedric Klapisch, Rachida Dati, Gilles PÃ©lisson 
									ChloÃ© Leclercq / Unifrance

schema.headline: Filmmaker Cedric Klapisch Collects French Cinema Award at Familial, Culture Ministry Ceremony

title: Cillian Murphyâ€™s â€™28 Years Laterâ€™ Return: Nia DaCosta Chose a â€˜Groundedâ€™ Scene Over a â€˜Big Return of the Superhero Momentâ€™ in â€˜The Bone Templeâ€™
description: Itâ€™s no spoiler that Cillian Murphy makes his return to the hit zombie franchise that made his name more than two decades on in â€œ28 Years Later: The
body:
Itâ€™s no spoiler that Cillian Murphy makes his return to the hit zombie franchise that made his name more than two decades on in â€œ28 Years Later: The Bone Temple.â€ Danny Boyle, who gave the actor his big screen break in â€œ28 Days Later,â€ revealed the info after the actor notably failed to show up in last yearâ€™s sequel â€œ28 Years Laterâ€ (it turned out that, no, he wasnâ€™t the emaciated zombie seen rising from a field).

	But those who donâ€™t want to know how and when he appears in Nia DaCostaâ€˜s blood-soaked sequel to the sequel â€” in cinemas with Sony Pictures â€”Â may want to stop reading now. 
	

	Murphy does indeed return in â€œThe Bone Temple,â€ reprising his role as Jim, the bicycle courier who famously woke up from a coma to find a London deserted and devastated by the Rage virus back in 2001. But itâ€™s not until right at the very end of the new film â€”Â and in a distinctly quiet scene that calms the tone down dramatically from the wildly unhinged mayhem seen over the previous 90 minutes. For director Nia DaCosta, working from Alex Garlandâ€™s script, that was entirely the point of what she hoped to achieve. 


	â€œBecause itâ€™s not a big â€˜return of the superheroâ€™ franchise moment,â€ she explains to Variety. â€œItâ€™s the return of the bike messenger.â€

	After reaching the climax of a prolonged and escalating period of madness with Ralph Fiennesâ€™ Dr Kelson, Jack Oâ€™Connellâ€™s Sir Lord Jimmy Crystal and Chi Lewis-Parryâ€™s Alpha zombie Samson, the film makes a sudden shift to a whole new setting, showing Murphyâ€™s Jim living in relative isolated safety, quite possibly in the same remote cottage he was left at the end of â€œ28 Days Later.â€ A quarter century on and he now has a daughter (who heâ€™s seen helping prepare for a history exam). 
	

	â€œThe fact that Alex wrote him teaching his daughter history andÂ thatâ€™s how he wanted to introduce him back into the story, I was like, ok, so thatâ€™s how we shoot it,â€ DaCosta says. â€œSo itâ€™s grounded. Itâ€™s not this big, bombastic moment. And I think itâ€™s powerful enough just to see him.â€ 

	It was certainly powerful enough to have audiences erupt into cheers in early screenings. 

	As it happens, audiences may have recognized Murphyâ€™s voice much earlier. As DaCosta was figuring out the title sequence of â€œThe Bone Templeâ€ and how to introduce the name of the new film on screen, she decided that what she needed to do was deploy a scene from the past. â€œSo we did it with sound, and the sound you hear is Cillianâ€™s from the first film saying â€˜Helloâ€™,â€ she says. â€œSo he actually appears in the film very early on.â€

	Fans of the franchise may also note a hat tip to itâ€™s origins in the big reveal with Murphy later on, with DaCosta using the original eerie track â€œIn a Heartbeat,â€ composed by John Murphy for â€œ28 Days Later.â€

	â€œThat was the biggest franchise-y thing we did,â€ she says. 

	Much like the final scene in â€œ28 Years Laterâ€ that introduced Oâ€™Conellâ€™s Crystal, the last act in â€œ28 Years Later: The Bone Templeâ€ with Murphy heavily suggests that thereâ€™s more to come. Thankfully, Sony has already greenlit a follow-up, with Garland back on writing duties.

	DaCosta claims it was â€œso much funâ€ making the film (and also admits it was â€œ100%â€ a reaction to having made a major MCU tentpole in â€œThe Marvelsâ€ and then an adaptation of Henrik Ibsenâ€™s â€œHeddaâ€). But sadly itâ€™s largely irrelevant whether or not sheâ€™d want to come back to direct the next one. 

	As she notes: â€œDanny called dibs.â€

schema.headline: Cillian Murphyâ€™s â€™28 Years Laterâ€™ Return: Nia DaCosta Chose a â€˜Groundedâ€™ Scene Over a â€˜Big Return of the Superhero Momentâ€™ in â€˜The Bone Templeâ€™

title: Mark Jones, â€˜Leprechaunâ€™ and â€˜Rumpelstiltskinâ€™ Director, Dies at 72
description: Mark Jones, a veteran animation writer and the director of B-horror comedy classics like â€œLeprechaunâ€ and â€œRumpelstiltskin,â€ died on Jan. 16 in Los
body:
Mark Jones, a veteran animation writer and the director of B-horror comedy classics like â€œLeprechaunâ€ and â€œRumpelstiltskin,â€ died on Jan. 16 in Los Angeles after a brief stay at West Hills Hospital. He was 72.

	George Saadi, a friend and collaborator of Jonesâ€™, confirmed his death to Variety. His 73rd birthday was Saturday, Jan. 17, and he missed the date by only a few hours.


	Jones was best known for writing and directing the 1992 cult classic â€œLeprechaun,â€ starring Jennifer Aniston and Warwick Davis. The film spawned seven sequels. â€œLeprechaun Returns,â€ the most recent installment, was released in 2018. His other notable credits include 1995â€™s â€œRumpelstiltskin,â€ a feature-length retelling of the classic fairytale, and 1997â€™s â€œNightMan,â€ a made-for-TV movie about a musician who is struck by lightning and gains the power to hear the frequency of evil.
	

	Jones got his start working on Saturday morning cartoons. He sold his first script to Filmation Studios before landing at DePatie Freleng, where he wrote â€œMister Magooâ€ and â€œPink Panther.â€ He then moved to legendary animation house Hanna-Barbera, where he wrote and story edited for shows like â€œSuper Friendsâ€ and several â€œScooby Dooâ€ projects.


	Some of his other notable animation writing credits include â€œFangface,â€ â€œYogiâ€™s Space Race,â€ â€œPlastic Man,â€ â€œHeathcliffâ€ and â€œMister T.â€

	Jones also worked on several live-action series through the â€˜80s and early â€˜90s. These included â€œThe Misadventures of Sheriff Lobo,â€ â€œRiptide,â€ â€œThe A-Team,â€ â€œThe Fall Guyâ€ and â€œSuperboy.â€ His most recent feature directing credits include 2013â€™s â€œScorned,â€ 2008â€™s â€œTriloquistâ€ and 2004â€™s â€œQuiet Kill.â€
	

	A private memorial service for Jones is planned for the near future.

schema.headline: Mark Jones, â€˜Leprechaunâ€™ and â€˜Rumpelstiltskinâ€™ Director, Dies at 72

title: Finn Wolfhardâ€™s â€˜SNLâ€™ Monologue Crashed by â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ BFFs Caleb McLaughlin and Gaten Matarazzo; Trio Say Theyâ€™re Grown and Ready for â€˜Adult Filmsâ€™
description:
Finn Wolfhardâ€˜s â€œSNLâ€ monologue was crashed by two of his best-known co-stars.

	Caleb McLaughlin and Gaten Matarazzo, who starred on â€œStranger Thin
body:
Finn Wolfhardâ€˜s â€œSNLâ€ monologue was crashed by two of his best-known co-stars.

	Caleb McLaughlin and Gaten Matarazzo, who starred on â€œStranger Thingsâ€ with Wolfhard, joined the actor in his monologue as he spoke about growing up onscreen and how heâ€™s now an adult. 

	â€œMy voice changed on camera, my first kiss was on camera, and the first time I learned what a woman looks like down there was on there as well,â€ before cutting to a howling Demogorgon.
	

	Unfortunately, he doesnâ€™t like the taste of alcohol, spitting up his first drink all over Marcello HernÃ¡ndez.


	Then the boys come out and talk about how strange it has been growing up onscreen, and all of the things people would say about them on Reddit. But at the end they joked that they are now ready to star inâ€¦â€adult films.â€

	Later in the episode, a sketch considered what might happen with some â€œStranger Thingsâ€ spinoffs, include â€œMike in Manhattan,â€ a â€œSex and the Cityâ€-esque series starring Wolfhard, McLaughlin and Matarazzo. The sketch also took a shot at Willâ€™s lengthy-coming out scene, saying that itâ€™s still going on. It also included â€œThe Wheeler Reportâ€ news show from Nancy, and a spinoff with Steve Harrington as an inner-city teacher.

	The sketch also included a scene from the rumored ninth episode that started an internet conspiracy theory.

	Watch Wolfhardâ€™s monologue below.

title: â€˜SNLâ€™ Mocks Trumpâ€™s Nobel Prize Envy, Colin Jostâ€™s Unhinged Pete Hegseth Promises â€˜USA is Going to Fâ€”â€˜ Countries Around the World
description: â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ mocked President Donald Trumpâ€™s egomania around the Nobel Peace Prize as well as the U.S. military action in Venezuela and Kri
body:
â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ mocked President Donald Trumpâ€™s egomania around the Nobel Peace Prize as well as the U.S. military action in Venezuela and Kristi Noemâ€™s incredibly callous response to the ICE shooting in Minneapolis in the cold open for the showâ€™s first episode of 2026.

	There was no shortage of political material to catch up on, and â€œSNLâ€ made the most of it in a faux Trump news conference and cabinet meeting. Colin Jost played an unhinged Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth. Jeremy Culhane played Vice President JD Vance, who whined about his recent trip to Greenland in a nod to Trumpâ€™s real-life outrageous threats that the U.S. should take over the Danish territory.
	

	â€œI came here to do two things,â€ Culhaneâ€™s Vance said. â€œKick bubble gum and chew ass. And Iâ€™m all out of bubble gum.â€


	James Austin Johnsonâ€™s Trump opened the segment at a podium with the Presidential seal talking about the Christmas holiday. 

	â€œI got what I wanted â€” my very own someone elseâ€™s Nobel Prize,â€ Johnsonâ€™s Trump said, a nod to the bizarre development in which Venezuelan opposition leader MarÃ­a Corina Machado presented her Nobel Peace Prize to Trump, in a bid to curry favor with him amid the upheaval in her home country . 

	â€œIn my stocking I got Maduro â€” NicolÃ¡s Maduro. We did a reverse-Santa on him. We came down the chimney with a bag and took him away,â€ Johnsonâ€™s Trump said, referring to the U.S.â€™s highly criticized move to capture the Venezuelan strongman who is now in jail in New York facing drug trafficking charges.

	Johnsonâ€™s Trump made a reference to â€œFrankensteinâ€ director Guillermo del Toro by mentioning â€œmy little cabinet of curiousities,â€ referring to his cabinet members as â€œvarious monsters and nightmares from the twisted mind of Guillermo del Trump.â€
	


	For Homeland Security Secretary Noem, Ashley Padilla came out in the cowboy hat similar to the one the real-life Noem wore as she sought to defend the shooting of a woman in Minneapolis by ICE agents on Jan. 7. â€œI want to give a quick shout out to my hair and makeup team who absolutely hate me,â€ Padillaâ€™s Noem said.

	As for the horrendous situation in Minneapolis, Padillaâ€™s Noem asked â€œHave we been perfect? Yes.â€ Then she gave a recruitment pitch for ICE. â€œIs your neck wider than your head? Are you currently wearing a Punisher T-shirt? Have you ever punched a hole in the wall because your son took a dance class? Grab a gun and saddle up, big boy.â€ 

	Jost then made a noisy entrance as Hegseth, who chugged an energy drink from an oversized mug and bragging about the military operation executed in Venezuela on Jan. 1. â€œWe went into Venezuela â€” we tea-bagged their country,â€ Jostâ€™s Hegseth said. 

	â€œWeâ€™re rocking out with our Câ€™s out all over the world,â€ Hegseth said while using a small weight in a sexually suggestive manner. He indicated that Iran was next in line to face the force of the U.S. force, in reference to the political protests that have left hundreds of people dead in the Middle Eastern country. â€œYou donâ€™t dare kill your protestors â€” thatâ€™s our thing,â€ Jostâ€™s Hegseth warned. â€œWeâ€™re going to F you right back.â€ 

	Johnsonâ€™s Trump came back to the podium to finish out the news conference. â€œEven I know youâ€™re doing that wrong,â€ he said, pointing to Jostâ€™s over-amped Hegseth. â€œThe midterms are canceled,â€ he declared before going into the classic â€œLive from New York, itâ€™s â€˜Saturday Nightâ€ transition into the credits.

	 In the final minutes of the show, before the cast gathered on stage for the traditional closing, the show paid tribute to Bob Weir, the founding member of the Grateful Dead, who died Jan. 10 at age 78. The legendary jam band also fronted by the late Jerry Garcia made two appearances on â€œSNL,â€ first in 1978 and then two years later.

	(Pictured: James Austin Johnson as Donald Trump and Colin Jost as Pete Hegseth in the cold open for the Jan. 17 episode of â€œSaturday Night Live.â€)

schema.headline: â€˜SNLâ€™ Mocks Trumpâ€™s Nobel Prize Envy, Colin Jostâ€™s Unhinged Pete Hegseth Promises â€˜USA is Going to Fâ€”â€˜ Countries Around the World

title: Matt Damon Says Netflix Wants Movies to Restate the â€˜Plot Three or Four Times in the Dialogueâ€™ Because Viewers are on â€˜Their Phones While Theyâ€™re Watchingâ€™
description: Matt Damon and Ben Affleck recently appeared on the â€œJoe Rogan Experienceâ€ to promote their new Netflix film â€œThe Rip,â€ and the long-time friends an
body:
Matt Damon and Ben Affleck recently appeared on the â€œJoe Rogan Experienceâ€ to promote their new Netflix film â€œThe Rip,â€ and the long-time friends and collaborators shared their thoughts on how the streamer is changing the way movies are made. 

	Damon pointed out that because viewers give a â€œvery different level of attentionâ€ to a movie at home versus in a theater, Netflix wants to push the action set pieces toward the front of the runtime. He also said there are behind-the-scenes discussions about reiterating â€œthe plot three or four times in the dialogueâ€ to account for people being on their phones.
	

	â€œThe standard way to make an action movie that we learned was, you usually have three set pieces. One in the first act, one in the second, one in the third,â€ Damon explained. â€œYou spend most of your money on that one in the third act. Thatâ€™s your finale. And now theyâ€™re like, â€˜Can we get a big one in the first five minutes? We want people to stay. And it wouldnâ€™t be terrible if you reiterated the plot three or four times in the dialogue because people are on their phones while theyâ€™re watching.â€™â€


	Affleck then cut in, adding that the streamer formula for successful content isnâ€™t the only way. He used Netflixâ€™s recent limited series hit â€œAdolescenceâ€ as a shining example.

	â€œBut then you look at â€˜Adolescence,â€™ and it didnâ€™t do any of that shit,â€ Affleck said. â€œAnd itâ€™s fucking great. And itâ€™s dark too. Itâ€™s tragic and intense. [Itâ€™s about] this guy who finds out his kid is accused of murder. There are long shots of the back of their heads. They get in the car, nobody says anything.â€
	

	While Damon thought shows like â€œAdolescenceâ€ are â€œthe exception,â€ Affleck said he felt the show â€œdemonstrates you donâ€™t have to doâ€ the Netflix tricks to please audiences.

	Watch the entire â€œJoe Rogan Experienceâ€ episode with Damon and Affleck here.

schema.headline: Matt Damon Says Netflix Wants Movies to Restate the â€˜Plot Three or Four Times in the Dialogueâ€™ Because Viewers are on â€˜Their Phones While Theyâ€™re Watchingâ€™

title: White House Threatened to Sue CBS Over â€˜Evening Newsâ€™ Interview With Trump
description: CBS News got more than it bargained for when it arranged for an interview earlier this week between President Donald Trump and anchor Tony Dokoupil
body:
CBS News got more than it bargained for when it arranged for an interview earlier this week between President Donald Trump and anchor Tony Dokoupil on his still-nascent tenure on â€œCBS Evening News.â€

	According to a report published Saturday by The New York Times, White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told producers and the anchor that Trump did not want the exchange edited. â€œHe said, â€˜Make sure you donâ€™t cut the tape, make sure the interview is out in full,â€™ Leavitt told Dokoupil and his executive producer, Kim Harvey. â€œHe said, â€˜If itâ€™s not out in full, weâ€™ll sue your ass off.'â€
	

	Such behavior is not unexpected when it comes to the Trump administration. Trump won a $16 million settlement from CBS Newsâ€™ parent company, Paramount, after he he sued over the way a â€œ60 Minutesâ€ interview with former Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris was edited in 2024. Legal experts felt Trumpâ€™s suit lacked merit, but Paramount was in a squeeze â€” it needed U.S. regulatory approval to sell itself to its new owner, now called Paramount Skydance. Trump has also won legal fees from Walt Disney Co., and worked to entangle other media outlets in legal skirmishes, including The Wall Street Journal and the BBC. Paramountâ€™s decision led in part to the exit of two senior CBS News executives with oversight of â€œ60 Minutesâ€ and other operations.


	In a statement Saturday, CBS News said Leavittâ€™s demands were not a factor in its decision to present Doukopilâ€™s 13-minute long interview with Trump, at a Ford plant in Michigan, in full: â€œThe moment we booked this interview we made the independent decision to air it unedited and in its entirety.â€
	

	Even so, CBS News has caved to a similar demand in the past, a move that can be seen to sacrifice its journalistic independence. In September, CBS News agreed to stopÂ editing taped interviews with newsmakers who appear on its Sunday public-affairs program â€œFace the Nationâ€ following complaints from the Trump administration over an appearance on the show by U.S. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem. She made made a number of false or unproven statements during her intervifew about Kilmar Abergo Garcia, the Salvadoran man who was deported despite his having protected legal status in the United States. CBS News offered just a portion of the overall interview with Noem and made the full exchange available online.

	The Trump threat comes even as CBS News has worked to give administration officials more time on its programs. Under recently installed editor in chief Bari Weiss, both â€œCBS Evening Newsâ€ and â€œ60 Minutesâ€ have found more room for talks with officials including U.S. Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth, for example, who spoke with Doukopil for three segments of a weekend broadcast following a U.S. military incursion on Venezuela. â€œ60 Minutesâ€ offered a report in October that had U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff and Trumpâ€™s son in law, Jared Kushner, offer insight into an effort to end recent conflicts in Gaza between Israel and Hamas.

	The threat from the White House was issued as Paramount Skydance is jockeying to acquire the media assets of Warner Bros. Discovery, even though that company has already brokered a deal to sell its streaming and studio operations to Netflix. Such a pact will also require regulatory approval.

schema.headline: White House Threatened to Sue CBS Over â€˜Evening Newsâ€™ Interview With Trump

title: â€˜KPop Demon Huntersâ€™ Star EJAE Gets Emotional as She Accepts Best Original Song for â€˜Goldenâ€™ at American Cinematheque Tribute: â€˜It Helped Bring Light in a Very Dark Time in my Lifeâ€™
description:
â€œKPop Demon Huntersâ€ continues to rack up the accolades.

	The filmâ€™s song â€œGoldenâ€ was honored by the American Cinematheque Tribute to the Arts for
body:
â€œKPop Demon Huntersâ€ continues to rack up the accolades.

	The filmâ€™s song â€œGoldenâ€ was honored by the American Cinematheque Tribute to the Arts for best original song. Songwriters EJAE and Mark Sonnenblick accepted the award. EJAE got emotional as she told the audience what songwriting meant to her. She called the song â€œa beautiful accident.â€

	â€œI thought I was gonna be a KPop Idol, but that didnâ€™t happen. But in my mid-20s, when I had to give up my dream to be a singer, I met a couple of KPop producers.â€ She explained how they asked her if she wanted to write a track, and she did â€“ about going through a breakup with her ex. â€œWhatâ€™s so weird was, after I was done, it weirdly helped me deal with the breakup better than talking to my girlfriends. Every melody, every word, had intent and expressed my emotion to its purest form.â€ 
	

	EJAE, who, along with Sonnenblick, won the Golden Globe and Critics Choice awards for best original song. EJAE talked about writing â€œGoldenâ€ and how she had her character, Rumi, in mind. â€œThe character was a fictional character, but the emotion was raw and very real. I think we all know how it feels to really crave for hope when it feels very hopeless, and it truly did help bring light in a very dark time in my life, actually to the point where I cried while singing the demo.â€

	Since the movieâ€™s release and success, she has been flooded with messages from fans sharing what the songs mean to them. â€œThe most received message I got was verbatim the sentence, â€˜Your song â€˜Goldenâ€™ saved me,â€™ and that is exactly the reason why youâ€™re write.â€
	


	Production designer Jack Fisk, who has never won an Oscar, was honored with the Career Achievement Award. His wife, Sissy Spacek, presented him with the award.

	Fisk, whose credits include â€œBadlands,â€ â€œMulholland Drive,â€ â€œThe Revenantâ€ and â€œMarty Supreme,â€ recalled being best friends with David Lynch. He said, â€œIn 1970, just out of art school, my best friend David Lynch and I drove to Los Angeles from Philadelphia in a rented U-Haul truck. He was going to the new American Film Institute, and I was looking for a job. I found one â€“ on a non-union film for $100 a week. â€“ It was holding traffic while the film company was shooting in a house about a quarter mile away. I was curious to be closer to the set, so I could see whatâ€™s going on. Then I found out that there was an art department on most films, and that became my goal â€“ to get into the Art Department.â€ He also worked with Lynch on â€œThe Straight Story.â€

	Fisk thanked Spacek and also shared how the two first met. â€œI met Terrence Malick, who was directing his first feature film, and he introduced me to a girl from Texas, Sissy Spacek, who would star in it. In 1972, Terry, Sissy, Martin Sheen, and a crew of 35 began filming â€˜Badlands,â€™ and my life was changed forever.â€

	He said he had no career regrets after five decades in the industry. â€œAs my friend David often said: â€œThe Art Life â€“ itâ€™s a great Life!â€

	â€œSinnersâ€ casting director Francine Maisler took time to thank the organization for â€œrecognizing the pivotal role that casting plays.â€ The Academy Awards will recognize casting for the first time at next monthâ€™s ceremony.

	â€One Battle after Anotherâ€ editor Andy Jurgensen called director Paul Thomas Anderson â€œan extraordinary mentor and collaborator.â€ Jurgensen added, â€œHeâ€™s taught me to go against convention, to be inventive, to let an audience know itâ€™s okay to laugh, to embrace mistakes and imperfections, and maybe most of all, when to know not to cut.â€

	The following are the Tribute to the Crafts honorees:

	Casting: â€œSinnersâ€ (Francine Maisler) â€“ Warner Bros. PicturesCinematography: â€œTrain Dreamsâ€ (Adolpho Veloso) â€“ NetflixChoreography: â€œWicked: For Goodâ€ (Christopher Scott) â€“ Universal PicturesCostume Design: â€œHeddaâ€ (Lindsay Pugh) â€“ Amazon MGM StudiosEditing: â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ (Andy Jurgensen) â€“ Warner Bros. PicturesHair and Makeup: â€œFrankensteinâ€ (Mike Hill, Cliona Furey & Jordan Samuel) â€“ NetflixProduction Design/Set Decoration/Prop Master: â€œFrankensteinâ€ (Tamara Deverell, Shane Vieau & Christopher Geggie) â€“ NetflixScore: â€œSinnersâ€ (Ludwig GÃ¶ransson) â€“ Warner Bros. title: Jamie-Lynn Sigler Kept Her MS Diagnosis a Secret for 25 Years Fearing Sheâ€™d â€˜Never Work Againâ€™
description: Jamie-Lynn Sigler got emotional during a recent interview with ABC (via Entertainment Weekly) in which she discussed her recent guest spot on â€œGreyâ€™
body:
Jamie-Lynn Sigler got emotional during a recent interview with ABC (via Entertainment Weekly) in which she discussed her recent guest spot on â€œGreyâ€™s Anatomyâ€ as a doctor with multiple sclerosis. She said the role was extremely personal, given that she was diagnosed with the condition 25 years ago and felt she needed to â€œkeep it a secretâ€ out of fear of losing work.

	She told ABC, â€œTo think back 25 years ago â€” when I was diagnosed and having to keep it a secret, thinking that if anybody knew that I had MS, that meant that I would never work again â€” and to now be in a position where my having MS inspired a role in a storyline on a show like â€˜Greyâ€™s Anatomy,â€™ I never would have believed you.â€
	

	Sigler, who was working on the legendary HBO drama â€œThe Sopranosâ€ at the time, was 20 years old when she was diagnosed with MS. She didnâ€™t go public with the news until 2017, when she sat down with the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

	On Jan. 15, Sigler appeared on â€œGreyâ€™s Anatomyâ€ as Dr. Laura Kaplan, a urologist with MS. In her episode, she gives Dr. Richard Webber, played by James Pickens Jr., advice on how to best treat his prostate cancer.

	Sigler said her goal with the part was to â€œshow someone in their powerâ€ and give an authentic depiction of someone living and thriving with MS.

	â€œMy very first take, where I do say the words that â€˜I have MS,â€™ was very emotional for me,â€ she said.

schema.headline: Jamie-Lynn Sigler Kept Her MS Diagnosis a Secret for 25 Years Fearing Sheâ€™d â€˜Never Work Againâ€™

title: 'Bringing Up Bates' Star Katie Clark Announces Pregnancy Loss
description:
'Bringing Up Bates'
                          Katie Clark Says She Lost Baby
body:
'Bringing Up Bates'
                          Katie Clark Says She Lost Baby
                      
                  
                                                                        Published 
                              
                January 17, 2026
                
                            3:30 PM PST
                                                                      |
                                                                Updated 
                                  January 17, 2026
                                5:50 PM PST
                                    
      
    
      
        
                    
                  
      
                    Instagram/@kgbates2000
          
    
          Katie Clark -- a star of the hit show "Bringing Up Bates" -- is going through a tragedy ... announcing she lost her pregnancy.
      
    
          The reality star announced the news on social media Friday ... sharing a clip which begins with her finding out she's pregnant.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          She then buys baby clothes and tells her husband Travis the news ... with the two happily embracing -- before the clip changes drastically.
      

          The second half of the clip takes viewers into a series of hospital rooms ... before showing a sobbing Katie who tells her friend she lost her baby.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Katie captioned the video, "I will spend the rest of my life missing you ğŸª½."
      
    
          Katie and Travis were expecting their third child. Their daughter, Hailey, turns three next month. Their son, Harvey, turned one in September.
      
    
          "Bringing Up Bates" ran from 2015 to 2021 and chronicled the lives of Gil and Kelly Jo Bates raising their 19 children.

title: Lamar Odom Arrested For DUI in Las Vegas
description:
Lamar Odom
                          Arrested For DUI in Vegas
body:
Lamar Odom
                          Arrested For DUI in Vegas
                      
                  
                                                                        Published 
                              
                January 17, 2026
                
                            12:08 PM PST
                                                                      |
                                                                Updated 
                                  January 17, 2026
                                5:50 PM PST
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Lamar Odom has been arrested in Las Vegas ... TMZ has learned.
      
    
          The former NBA star was arrested and booked for driving under the influence after he was pulled over early Saturday morning. The incident is still under investigation.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          He was also slapped with two traffic violations -- driving more than 41+ miles per hour over the limit and improper lane change/failure to maintain lane.
      

          At the time of publishing, it appears Odom is still in custody.
      
    
          Odom has a documented history of drug and alcohol addiction. He was previously arrested for DUI in 2013.
      
    
          In 2015, Odom nearly died of an overdose ... and his wife, KhloÃ© Kardashian, rushed to his side to nurse him back to health. Their relationship ended not long after Odom relapsed in 2016.
      
    
          Odom -- who played for four teams across a 14-year NBA career -- committed himself to sobriety in recent years ... and even offered help to others struggling with addiction, like Bam Margera, via several rehabilitation centers he owns.
      
    
          We broke down all of Odom's struggles in our documentary "TMZ Presents: Lamar Odom: Sex, Drugs, & Kardashians" ... now available to stream on YouTube.
      
    
          Story developing ...

title: Janice Dickinson Spotted After Sharing Alleged Injuries From Reality Show Fall
description:
Janice Dickinson
                          In Your Face, Everyone ...
                          B
body:
Janice Dickinson
                          In Your Face, Everyone ...
                          Back in Public After Sharing Injury Pics
                      
                  
                                                                        Published 
                              January 17, 2026
                            5:20 PM PST
                                                                      |
                                                                Updated 
                                  January 17, 2026
                                7:43 PM PST
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Janice Dickinson's still smiling despite everyone talking about a traumatic moment in her life this week ... looking happy after we posted photos of alleged injuries she says she sustained in a nasty fall.
      
    
          The model and television personality stepped out in Los Angeles Friday ... grinning wide while walking down the block in a denim jacket.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          She wore a pair of glasses and let her hair fall down her back ... and, looked far more put together than she did with the extensive scabbing on her face back in 2022.
      

          We obtained photos of facial injuries Dickinson says she suffered while working on the show "I'm a Celebrity... South Africa" ... which affected her forehead, nose, lips and chin.
      
    
          Dickinson claims she suffered head and facial injuries after going to the toilet at night during the show's jungle camp and tripping ... and, she's now suing ITV Studios -- the British broadcaster -- over the alleged incident.
      
    
          ITV told us they don't recognize Janice's version of events ... and, the studio also claims it paid Janice's medical expenses.
      
    
          This legal fight isn't over ... but, Janice looks happy for people to see and hear her side of the story.
